text.p: Gold prices lumbered lower on Thursday afternoon to fresh 40-month lows below $350 an ounce amid steady selling pressure, dealers said.
"Every time gold pokes its head above $350 an ounce it gets sold," one said, pinning the selling on Australian producers, speculators and investment funds.
Bullion was fixed at $348.00 an ounce, a fresh low fixing since September 15, 1993, and down $1.80 from the morning's level.
Most activity was concentrated on New York's Comex futures market, with volumes in Europe remaining light, dealers said.
Prices were bid as low as $346.50 ahead of the fixing, then firmed slightly to hold just above $348.
Some dealers expected prices to range between $348 and $352 for the time being.
But $345 is frequently cited by technical analysts as the next likely target for gold.
Dealers were doubtful that gold, which was oversold with an RSI of 25, would make much progress even if it managed a bounce.
The surging U.S. dollar, which had put crushing pressure on gold earlier this week, was off its 30-plus months highs against the mark and yen posted yesterday.
But sentiment remained darkened by fears of central bank gold sales ahead of European Monetary Union and the potential of renewed producer hedging, dealers said.
In sharp contrast to gold, silver was up five cents from Wednesday's close, at $4.77/$4.79 an ounce.
"Even though gold is weaker, silver can't be budged and the gold-silver ratio is really moving," a dealer said, noting that market players were buying silver as they sold gold as a play on the ratio.
The gold-silver ratio was close to 73, down from about 77 at the start of the year.
Platinum, however, has been closely shadowing gold and also fell to its lowest fixing since September 15, 1993 when it was fixed at $355.85 per ounce.
Dealers said platinum was attracting very little interest despite its low price.
"It has been caught in the downdraft from gold and has virtually no life of its own," a dealer said.
Palladium, which has been holding steady despite weakness in gold and platinum, was barely changed at $120.50/$121.50.
